p: Our work confirms the work by others that non-native vegetation cover, abundance, growth and population growth rates decline when deer browse pressure is reduced or even eliminated ( Kalisz et al. 2014 ; DÃ¡valos et al. 2015b ) although see Averill et al. (this issue). We suggest that non-native plants, at least the three species in our study ( A. petiolata, B. thunbergii, M. vimineum) are indicators of earthworm invasion and high deer abundance, and that these two factors pose greater threats, singly and in combination, to native vegetation than do non-native plants.
